title: Development of the most cost-efficient hydrogen production unit based on anion exchange membrane electrolysis
abstract: The CHANNEL proposal brings together world-leading and highly experienced industrial and research partners with AEM electrolyser expertise to address the topic New Anion Exchange electrolyser - FCH-02-4-2019. The main objective of CHANNEL is to develop a low cost and efficient electrolyser stack and balance of plant (BoP) that will become a game-changer for the electrolyser industry. The concept is to construct an AEM electrolyser unite using low cost materials, using state-of-the-art anion exchange membranes and ionomers, non-PGM electrocatalysts, as well as low-cost porous transport layers, current collectors and bi-polar plates. This will enable the development of an electrolyser technology at a capital cost (CAPEX) equal or below classical alkaline electrolysis. However, in contrast to the alkaline technology, the CHANNEL AEM electrolyser will have an efficiency and current density operation close to the one of proton exchange membrane electrolyser (PEMWE). The CHANNEL stack will not only result in decreased electrolyser part count, but it will also be able to operate at differential pressure, as well as under dynamic operation, optimal for producing high quality, low cost hydrogen from renewable energy sources.

motivations: Current hydrogen production methods are not cost-efficient, hindering widespread adoption.
There is a need for an electrolyser technology that balances cost and efficiency to support the production of low-cost hydrogen from renewable energy sources.
objectives: Develop a low-cost and efficient anion exchange membrane (AEM) electrolyser stack and balance of plant (BoP).
Achieve a capital cost (CAPEX) equal to or below classical alkaline electrolysis while maintaining efficiency and current density comparable to proton exchange membrane electrolyser (PEMWE).
methods: Utilize low-cost materials, including state-of-the-art anion exchange membranes and ionomers, non-PGM electrocatalysts, and low-cost porous transport layers, current collectors, and bi-polar plates.
Design an AEM electrolyser unit capable of operating at differential pressure and under dynamic conditions.
results: Produce a cost-efficient hydrogen production unit with reduced electrolyser part count.
Enable the production of high-quality, low-cost hydrogen from renewable energy sources.
llama_json.research_subject: Development of a cost-efficient hydrogen production unit based on anion exchange membrane electrolysis

motivations: The need for a cost-efficient and effective hydrogen production unit is crucial for the electrolyser industry.
Current electrolyser technologies either have high capital costs or are not efficient enough.
objectives: Develop a low-cost and efficient electrolyser stack and balance of plant (BoP) using low-cost materials and state-of-the-art anion exchange membranes and ionomers.
Achieve a capital cost (CAPEX) equal or below classical alkaline electrolysis while maintaining efficiency and current density operation close to proton exchange membrane electrolyser (PEMWE).
Ensure the developed electrolyser can operate at differential pressure and under dynamic operation, optimal for producing high quality, low cost hydrogen from renewable energy sources.
methods: Construct an Anion Exchange Membrane (AEM) electrolyser unit using low-cost materials, state-of-the-art anion exchange membranes and ionomers, non-PGM electrocatalysts, and low-cost porous transport layers, current collectors and bi-polar plates.
Compare the efficiency and current density operation of the developed AEM electrolyser with classical alkaline electrolysis and proton exchange membrane electrolyser (PEMWE).
results: Development of a cost-efficient and efficient electrolyser stack and balance of plant (BoP).
Achievement of a capital cost (CAPEX) equal or below classical alkaline electrolysis while maintaining high efficiency.
Production of high quality, low cost hydrogen from renewable energy sources.
openai_json.research_subject: Development of a cost-efficient hydrogen production unit based on anion exchange membrane electrolysis

motivations: Current electrolyser technologies face a trade-off between high efficiency (PEM) and low cost (alkaline), limiting widespread adoption of hydrogen production.
There is a need for cost-effective hydrogen production systems that can efficiently operate with renewable energy sources.
objectives: Develop a low-cost and efficient anion exchange membrane (AEM) electrolyser stack and balance of plant that combines the advantages of both alkaline and PEM technologies.
Create an electrolyser technology with capital costs equal to or below classical alkaline electrolysis while achieving efficiency and current density close to PEM electrolysers.
methods: Utilize state-of-the-art anion exchange membranes and ionomers with non-PGM electrocatalysts to reduce material costs.
Implement low-cost porous transport layers, current collectors, and bi-polar plates in the electrolyser design.
Design the system for differential pressure and dynamic operation capabilities.
results: Achievement of a game-changing electrolyser technology with reduced part count and lower capital costs.
Production of high-quality, low-cost hydrogen optimized for renewable energy sources.
Demonstration of an AEM electrolyser combining the cost advantages of alkaline technology with the performance benefits of PEM technology.
anthropic_json.research_subject: Cost-efficient hydrogen production using anion exchange membrane electrolysis technology
